natural problem: What is the sum of all the solutions of $x = \left|2x-|60-2x|\right|$?
natural solution: We take cases on the sign of $60-2x.$ If $60-2x \ge 0,$ then the equation becomes \[x = \left| 2x - (60-2x) \right| = \left| 4x - 60 \right|.\]Therefore, either $x = 4x-60,$ which gives $x=20,$ or $x=-(4x-60),$ which gives $x=12.$ Both solutions satisfy $60-2x \ge 0,$ so they are valid.

If $60-2x<0,$ then the equation becomes \[x = \left| 2x + (60-2x) \right| = 60,\]which satisfies $60-2x<0,$ so $x=60$ is the only solution in this case. The sum of all the solutions is therefore $12 + 20 + 60 = \boxed{92}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. x = abs (2 * x - abs (60 - 2 * x))"
shows  "sum_list (solutions_to (\<lambda>x. x = abs (2 * x - abs (60 - 2 * x)))) = 92"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the solutions of $x = \left|2x-|60-2x|\right|$? The final Answer is 92
 ### Proof
 We take cases on the sign of $60-2x.$ If $60-2x \ge 0,$ then the equation becomes \[x = \left| 2x - (60-2x) \right| = \left| 4x - 60 \right|.\]Therefore, either $x = 4x-60,$ which gives $x=20,$ or $x=-(4x-60),$ which gives $x=12.$ Both solutions satisfy $60-2x \ge 0,$ so they are valid.
 If $60-2x<0,$ then the equation becomes \[x = \left| 2x + (60-2x) \right| = 60,\]which satisfies $60-2x<0,$ so $x=60$ is the only solution in this case. The sum of all the solutions is therefore $12 + 20 + 60 = \boxed{92}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. x = abs (2 * x - abs (60 - 2 * x))"
shows  "sum_list (solutions_to (\<lambda>x. x = abs (2 * x - abs (60 - 2 * x)))) = 92"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of all real numbers x that satisfy the equation $x = |2x - |60 - 2x||$. The final answer is 92.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. abs (2*x - abs (60 - 2*x)) = x"
shows  "sum x {x. abs (2*x - abs (60 - 2*x)) = x} = 92"

 If $60-2x<0,$ then the equation becomes \[x = \left| 2x + (60-2x) \right| = 60,\]which satisfies $60-2x<0,$ so $x=60$ is the only solution in this case. The sum of all the solutions is therefore $12 + 20 + 60 = \boxed{92}.$
 *)

fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. abs (2*x - abs (60 - 2*x)) = x"
shows  "sum x {x. abs (2*x - abs (60 - 2*x)) = x} = 92"
